Lewisburg

James Riv. and Kan. Co. v. Thompson & Teays. 1846. July Term.

(Absent Brooke, J.)

1. The franchise as well as the property of the citizen may be taken for public uses, upon making just compensation therefor. 2. An act directs the public engineer to lay off a road and sites for bridges thereon, and declares that upon the return of the plats thereof to the clerks’ offices of the County Courts in which the road located lies, the land shall be vested in the Commonwealth for the use of the road. Held : That on a compliance with the law, the title to the land on which the road is located, and the sites of the bridges are fixed, is vested in the Commonwealth; and that the Commonwealth or her grantee may maintain ejectment therefor against the former owner. This was an action of ejectment brought by the James River and Kanawha Company against Philip *271R. Thompson and James T. Teays, to recover the land on both banks of Cole river, on which the abutments of a bridge across that river were built by Thompson and Teays. The Judge of the Circuit Superior Court of Kanawha county, in which the suit was brought, being a stockholder in the James River and Kanawha Company, sent the cause to the Circuit Superior Court of Fayette county, where it came on to be tried in Septemtember 1840, when the jury found a special verdict. The substance of that special verdict was: That on the 14th of February 1821, an act passed the General Assembly authorizing Philip R. Thompson and Stephen Teays to build a tollbridge across Cole river, from the lands of Thompson near the mouth of the said river, to the lands of Teays on the opposite side thereof; and provided that the benefits of the act should be forfeited, if the bridge was not commenced within two years, and completed within four years thereafter. That up to the 17th of January 1828, no step was taken by Thompson and Teays to erect said bridge. And that on that day another act was passed extending the time for completing the bridge for four years from the date of the act. That on the 80th of January 1829, an act was passed for the extension of the Kanawha turnpike road to Big Sandy river; by which act the James River Company were authorized and required to cause the Kanawha turnpike road to be extended from the western termination thereof to the mouth of Big Sandy river. For this purpose, the principal engineer of the State was directed to lay out the road, to indicate the sites of the bridges and culverts, which he might deem necessary; to describe the number, kind and situation of the bridges; and to deliver to the clerks of the County Courts of Cabell and Kanawha plats or maps of so much of the said road as might be within their respective counties, to be by them respectively recorded. And *272the act provided that thereupon the land over which the said roa<^ should be located, should become ipso facto vested in the Commonwealth, for the use of the road, The act provides a remedy by which the owners of ^an<^ over ^ie roa<^ is located, may obtain compensation for the damages sustained by the location of ^ roa<^) an<^ the vesting of the land in the Commonwealth. This remedy is to be pursued within one year from the time when the maps or plats are recorded by the clerks of the respective County Courts, and if not commenced within that time the said owners of land are to be deemed to have relinquished to the Commonwealth all claim to damages arising from the execution of the act. And the damages ascertained to be sustained by the land owners are to be paid by the president and directors of the James River Company, out of any unexpended funds in their hands. The act gives to the James River Company the superintendence of the construction of the road, and the authority to collect tolls thereon. That in the fall of the year 1829, the State engineer located the road; and on the 21st and 22d days of November 1829, filed in the clerk’s office of the County Court of Kanawha county a map of the location of said road within said county.* That the engineer located the road crossing Cole river ; and at the same time, located a site for a bridge across said river, at the spot where the bridge of Thompson and Teays now stands, in the line of the road located. And at the same time he located a road down the banks of said river for a ford or ferry. This road to the ford left the line which passed the point at which *273the site for the bridge was located, a short distance on one side of the river, and came into it again a short distance on the other side. That at the time of the passage of the act of the 14th of February 1821, and for many years previous thereto, the old State road ran near the Kanawha river, crossing Cole river at its mouth, some distance below the point located as the site for the bridge. And that the turnpike road located as aforesaid, after crossing Cole river does not unite with the old State road within fourteen miles of the said river. That in the fall of 1830 Thompson and James Teays commenced the construction of the bridge in controversy across Cole river, upon the site located by the engineer as aforesaid. That some time in January 1832, the said bridge when nearly completed was swept away by a freshet. That on the 6th of February 1832, another act was passed giving to Thompson and Mary 'Teays, the widow of Stephen Teays, the further time of eight months from the 17th January 1832, to complete said bridge. And that on the 20th of March 1832, during the same session, another act was passed, by which it is provided that nothing in the act of the 6th of February should be considered as affecting, or changing in any manner whatever, the respective rights vested in the James River Company, and Thompson and Teays, previous to the passage of said act. That before the expiration of the time limited by the act of the 6th of f’ebruary 1832, Thompson and Teays completed their bridge; and that about the time the bridge was completed, the turnpike road on both sides of Cole river was completed, leaving on the west side of the river about fifty feet, and on the east side about one hundred feet; which unfinished portions were subsequently constructed by said Thompson and Teays. That on the 14th of December 1832, the James River Company adopted a resolution, instructing the su*274perintendent of the road to institute the necessary legal proceedings to abate the bridge erected by Thompson and Teays, and to prevent the collection of tolls thereat; and to cause the banks of the river to be graduated for ^ at that place designated by the principal engineer: a copy of which resolution was served upon Thompson and Teays. Upon the representation thereof to the General Assembly, the assembly, on the 28th of February, passed a resolution instructing the James River Company to abstain, until further directions from the General Assembly, from any proceedings to abate the bridge erected by Thompson and Teays over Cole river; or from any legal proceedings affecting the rights of said Thompson and Teays; and that they report fully all the facts relating to the said bridge to the next succeeding General Assembly. That on the 16th of March 1832, the act incorporating the James River and Kanawha Company was passed; which act, with all subsequent acts in relation to the James River and Kanawha Company, passed prior to the commencement of this action, are made a part of the special verdict. That the James River and Kanawha Company was organized in the year 1835; and that the property belonging to the James River Company, including said turnpike road, was transferred to the James River and Kanawha Company on the 27th of June 1835; pursuant to the provisions of the acts last aforesaid. That before the organization of the James River and Kanawha Company, the James River Company, in pursuance of their resolution of the 14th December 1832, constructed the road leading down to the ford over Cole river; and since that time, that road has been used by the James River Company and the James River and Kanawha Company whenever Cole river was fordable. That the entire extension of the turnpike road to the mouth of Big Sandy was completed, and gates erected *275in the summer of 1833, pursuant to the acts establishing it. That Philip R. Thompson, at his own expense, con-i i -3 structed a road from the turnpike road on the east side of Cole river to intersect the old State road on the bank of Kanawha river, which road, some years afterwards, ' n .r_ _ was established by the County Court of Kanawha as public road. And from the time of its construction the old State road above the point of intersection was discontinued, and below the point of intersection was and still is continued; and that the ferries across Cole and Kanawha rivers, as they were established by law before any of the abovementioned acts, are still used. That the land on which the bridge has been erected by Thompson and Teays, and the bridge site, are the subjects of controversy in this suit; and that the defendants were and still are in possession thereof. In addition to the facts found by the jury, it was agreed by the parties, that before the location of the turnpike road across Cole river, the ancestor of the defendants was the owner in fee of the land in question; and that the defendants continue to be such owners; except so far as the right to said land has been vested in the Commonwealth and the James River and Kanawha Company by the law and the facts found in the special verdict. Upon the special verdict and the facts agreed, the Court below gave judgment for the defendants j from which judgment the James River and Kanawha Company applied to this Court for a supersedeas,■ which was granted. G. N. Johnson, for the appellants.

When the acts of February 1821, and 1828, were passed, the public road ran near the Kanawha river, and there was a ferry at the mouth of Cole river: and it was the intention, in authorizing the building of the *276bridge provided for in these acts, to accommodate the travel on that road. For nine years Thompson and Teays neglected to build their bridge; nor did they take the first step towards it, until the James River Company had, in pursuance of the act of 1829, proceeded to locate their turnpike along the Kanawha, fix the site of their bridge over Cole river,- and then Thompson and Teays placed theirs precisely on the site located by the company. I submit that the acts of 1821 and 1828 do not authorize Thompson and Teays to build their bridge at the place they have put it. The first act says they shall build their bridge near the mouth of Cole river. The last says at or near the mouth of Cole river. And this bridge is built neither at, or in the sense of the statute, near the mouth of the river.

The act of January 1829, makes it the duty of the James River Company to locate the turnpike road to the mouth of Big Bandy river. This duty the company was bound to perform; and in so doing, to locate the site for a bridge across Cole river. This act vests the land in the Commonwealth, on the recording of the plat by the clerk of the County Court; and prescribes the mode of ascertaining the damages and compensating the owners. If, then, Thompson and Teays had fixed the site of their bridge before the location by the engineer, this act would have vested the land in the Commonwealth ; and their right would have been, not to the land, but to such damages as the land as a site for a bridge, was worth. Tuckahoe Canal Co. v. Tuckahoe Railroad Co., 11 Leigh 42. This case shews clearly, that there is no limit to the power to take private property, whether that of a person or a corporation, for public uses, except to make just compensation for it.

If we look to the terms of the act, there can be no doubt that the land was vested in the Commonwealth, when the survey was made and recorded. The act does not say the road or the fight of way, but the land shall *277be vested. The only question, therefore, that can arise, is, as to the estate which vests. But the damages are to be assessed for the whole land, and the land is vested ; and therefore it must be the whole fee. If, however, the whole fee is not vested in the Commonwealth, and through the Commonwealth in the James Rivet' and . , , Kanawha Company, succeeding as it does to her rights in this road, still any estate which gives the right of possession, will sustain this action; and if this be a base fee, determinable by the going down of the road, it is sufficient to entitle the company to recover.

Michie and Patton, for the appellees.

The act of 1829, extending the turnpike to the mouth of Big Sandy river, is unconstitutional; because it does not provide for a just compensation to the owners of the land to be taken for the road. Crenshaw v. Slate River Co., 6 Rand. 245; James River and Kanawha Co. v. Turner, 9 Leigh 313; Van Horne v. Dorrance, 2 Dali. R. 304. The act divests the owner of his land; and the only compensation it provides for him is a suit. A suit, in which a judgment is forbidden to be rendered, but he is to receive a certificate which is to be paid out of the unappropriated funds of the James River Company : funds which never existed. And thus the just compensation secured by the constitution, is a claim which may not be enforced against a company which cannot pay it. It is true, this law was enacted when the Commonwealth was the company; but she made no provision for the payment of the damages: and she has kept up the separate organization of the company; and has most carefully avoided making herself responsible for its debts.

It is certainly true, that the Commonwealth has a right of passage over the land within her borders; and may confer upon any citizen the right to construct the way, upon making compensation to the owner. But *278when she has once done this, and obtained the passage, she cannot take away the right she has conferred, and give it to another. Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Co. v. Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Co., 4 Gill & John. 1. case a^so decides, that when from the nature of the case the line of way is not defined in the act, it is the right of the party to lay down the line as he may think best; and this line cannot be interfered with. In 1828 the General Assembly gave to Thompson and Teays the right to build a bridge over Cole river; and they had a right to build it at any place within the restrictions of the act. The act says near the mouth of Cole river. It is within that restriction. It says on the land of Thompson and Teays, and it is within that. Having then built their bridge according to the provisions of the statute, how is it that they are to be deprived of their franchise by the action of á company, which derives all its authority from the act of 1829 ?

When it is proposed to divest the property of the citizen, a compliance with the statute which authorizes it must be shewn. This act authorizes the location of one road, not of several; and as it is shewn that the engineer located the road to the ford or ferry; and that the company have been in the habit of using that road ; and as the map and survey does not extend the road to the bridge on either side, the owners could have no reason to suppose that their right to their own property was thereby divested. If, indeed, their right is divested, then, though the plat does not shew the location of the road to the bridge, and though Thompson and Teays have built their bridge with the apparent acquiescence of the James River Company, they are deprived of their franchise, and their property; and under the provisions of the act of 1829, they are deprived of all compensation for their loss.

It must have been contemplated by the Commonwealth, that Thompson and Teays would erect their *279bridge along the line of travel on the road; and she must therefore have intended that they should hold their franchise; and that the James River Company should take in subordination to their rights. And this is confirmed by the act of 1832, passed after the bridge had been located and nearly completed at its present position.

The act of 1829, by virtue of which the James River and Kanawha, Company claims in this action, says that the land shall be vested in the Commonwealth for the use of the road. Upon this act the question arises, what is thereby vested in the Commonwealth ? The law does not say the fee shall be vested: and when we look to the purpose and object of the statute, we see that the right of way is all that is necessary. We must presume, therefore, that this alone was intended, because it is to be presumed that the General Assembly has not interfered further with individual rights and property than was necessary for the public convenience.

Almost every act passed by the General Assembly for the making of turnpike roads, provides for the condemnation of land for the purpose. And yet this Court in Bolling v. Mayor of Petersburg, 3 Rand. 563, alluding to the principle that in England the public has a mere right of way, over the land, draws the same conclusion from our own legislation on the subject. Where then is the plain language of the statute which takes the fee in the land ? What is the public necessity which requires that the land and not the right of way over the land shall be vested in the Commonwealth ? And without which necessity it has been held that there was no right to take the soil. Peck v. Smith, 1 Conn. R. 103; Smith’s Leading Cas. 44 Law Libr. 144.

The Attorney General, for the appellants.

The right of property in the land in controversy depends upon the true construction of the act of 1829. *280Sup. Rev. Code 463. We say that by this act the land. was vested in the. Commonwealth, and by the act of March 1832, was transferred to the appellants. The act saYs the lan(3 shall be vested in the Commonwealth for tpe llse 0f qie r0ad. The land is vested. Take either the popular or legal signification of this term, and it includes every thing in and upon it. 1 Thom. Coke Litt. 230, 4 a. It also conveys an estate equal to a fee simple. At common law it is true words of inheritance were necessary to pass a fee, but by our statute these words are dispensed with. Prima facie, therefore, we have a fee simple estate in the land.

But it is said the words “ for the use of the road,” limited the grant both in its duration and character. The Court will not give this effect to these words, if the use of them may be accounted for: and this will be done by looking to the fact that the Commonwealth conducts her proceedings in relation to various objects by distinct bodies. Thus there is the Literary fund, the Board of public works, the Southwestern road, and the Kanawha road: and the words in question were intended to shew that the land was to be vested in the. Commonwealth for the use of this last road.

It is true that in England the public are considered as having only the right of way, whilst the land still belongs to the coterminous owner. But the right of eminent domain entitles the Commonwealth to take either the whole land, or the easement; and how much shall be taken must therefore depend upon the judgment and discretion of the General Assembly. This power to take private property for public uses, is a power to be exercised both in peace and in war, in relation to both real and personal property, and the only limitation upon it is, that just compensation be made to the owner for it. We must therefore in every case look to the statute to see what the Legislature has in its discretion deemed it proper to take.

*281It is said the act is unconstitutional because just compensation has not been provided for the persons whose land is taken. This provision of the Constitution has never been construed to require that the compensation shall be made before the property is taken; nor has it been so considered in Massachusetts, where they have a similar provision. Boston and Roxb. Milldam Corp. v. Newman, 12 Pick. R. 467. And it is obvious that in many cases which might be mentioned, and which are of frequent occurrence, it would be wholly impracticable. On this point the Court is referred to James River and Kanawha Company v. Anderson, 12 Leigh 278; Tuckahoe Canal Co. v. Tuckahoe Railroad Co., 11 Leigh 42; Case v. Thompson, 6 Wend. R. 634; Rogers v. Bradshaw, 20 John. R. 735; Jerome v. Ross, 7 John. Ch. R. 315; Wheelock v. Pratt, 4 Wend. R. 647; Bloodgood v. Mohawk and Hudson R. R. Co., 18 Wend. R. 9.

But it is said this act gives not money but a suit. The James River Company was the mere agent of the Commonwealth, and any demands against the company was a demand against the Commonwealth. It is true the damages were to be paid out of the unexpended balance on hand; but as the right to payment for the damages vested immediately, even before the execution of the work, the owners of land entitled to damages, were given priority of payment: and if the fund provided for their satisfaction was not sufficient, the faith of the State was pledged for their indemnity.

It is insisted, for the appellees, that the General Assembly have not, and have not intended to deprive Thompson and Teays of their right to the ground on which their bridge is located. The cases of Charles River Bridge v. Warren Bridge, 7 Pick. R. 344, of The Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Co. v. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Co. 4 Gill & John. 1; and of the Tuckahoe Canal Co. v. The Tuckahoe Rail*282road Co. shew that a grant is not a monopoly, unless expressly so provided. It cannot then be pretended with any show of reason, that the grant to Thompson and Teays to build a bridge over Cole river, restrained ^ie ®eneral Assembly from making a road from Charleston to the mouth of Big Sandy river. This is what has been done; and after the road and the site of the bridge over Cole river had been located, Thompson and Teays placed their bridge precisely upon the ground located for a bridge by the James River Company. To suppose that the General Assembly intended that this should be done by Thompson and Teays; and thus that double tolls should be collected on the road, is in opposition to the principles of Stokes v. Upper Appomattox Co. 3 Leigh 318.

It is said that the act of 1832 confirms the act of Thompson and Teays in building their bridge on its present site. But grants by the public are to be taken strictly; and only to be intended for the purpose expressed in them. 2 Black. Comm. 347-8; 6 Bac. Abr. Prerogative 518, 614. The correct principle is, that the grantee knows everything about the matter of the grant, and the Legislature does not; and therefore the facts must be fairly represented to the Legislature or the grant will be void. That the General Assembly was not informed of the facts in this case, the act of March 1832 abundantly proves.

The map is made a part of the special verdict; and the jury refer to the stations and lines marked upon it to designate the site of the bridge, and the roads located by the engineer, as well as the old road; but the map is not in the possession of the reporter, and he is therefore obliged to describe the localities as well as he can without it.

 By the Court.

The Court is of opinion, that the matters of law arising upon the facts found in the special verdict, and the facts agreed by the parties, is for the plaintiff: therefore that the said judgment is erroneous ; that the said judgment be reversed and annulled ; and that the plaintiff recover against the defendants his costs here expended. And this Court proceeding to give such judgment as the said Circuit Court ought to have given, it is considered that the plaintiff recover *283against the defendants the land in the declaration mentioned, located by the engineer for the use of the Kanawha turnpike road, and in the occupancy of the defeudants, and one cent damages found by the jury, and his costs. Whereupon the plaintiff prays a writ, &c. and to him it is granted, &c.
